content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student sets up a galvanic cell with one half-cell made with a tin electrode and a <math alttext="S n with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Sn</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> solution and the second half-cell made with a cobalt electrode and a <math alttext="C o with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Co</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> solution, as shown. The salt bridge contains <math alttext="K N O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>KNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>. (a) The following table provides standard reduction potentials.Half-Reaction<math alttext="E naught, in volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>V</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math><math alttext="S n with a positive 2 charge, plus 2 electrons, reacts to produce S n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Sn</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>→</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>Sn</mi></math><math alttext="negative 0.138" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>0.138</mn></math><math alttext="C o with a positive 2 charge, plus 2 electrons, reacts to produce C o" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Co</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>→</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>Co</mi></math><math alttext="negative 0.277" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>0.277</mn></math>(i) Given the balanced equation <math alttext="S n with a positive 2 charge, plus C o, reacts to produce S n, plus C o with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Sn</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>Co</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>Sn</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>Co</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math>, determine the standard cell potential, <math alttext="E naught sub cell" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msubsup><mi>E</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow><mo>∘</mo></msubsup></math>.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student sets up a galvanic cell with one half-cell made with a tin electrode and a <math alttext="S n with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Sn</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> solution and the second half-cell made with a cobalt electrode and a <math alttext="C o with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Co</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> solution, as shown. The salt bridge contains <math alttext="K N O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>KNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>. (a) The following table provides standard reduction potentials.Half-Reaction<math alttext="E naught, in volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>V</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math><math alttext="S n with a positive 2 charge, plus 2 electrons, reacts to produce S n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Sn</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>→</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>Sn</mi></math><math alttext="negative 0.138" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>0.138</mn></math><math alttext="C o with a positive 2 charge, plus 2 electrons, reacts to produce C o" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Co</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>→</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>Co</mi></math><math alttext="negative 0.277" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>0.277</mn></math>(i) Given the balanced equation <math alttext="S n with a positive 2 charge, plus C o, reacts to produce S n, plus C o with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Sn</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>Co</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>Sn</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>Co</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math>, determine the standard cell potential, <math alttext="E naught sub cell" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msubsup><mi>E</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow><mo>∘</mo></msubsup></math>.

(ii) Is the value of <math alttext="delta G naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>G</mi><mo>°</mo></math> for the overall electrochemical reaction greater than, less than, or equal to zero? Justify your answer based on the value of <math alttext="E naught sub cell" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msubsup><mi>E</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow><mo>∘</mo></msubsup></math>.

(b) A representation of the cobalt half-cell before the reaction starts is shown in diagram <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The student observes that as the cell operates, the solution becomes a darker shade of pink. In diagram <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, complete the representation of the cobalt half-cell after the cell has operated for a short time. Be sure that mass is conserved. The balance of charge is not necessary, and all species may not need to be shown in the drawing.

(c) A second galvanic cell is constructed such that <math alttext="the molar concentration of S n with a positive 2 charge, equals 1.0 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><msup><mi>Sn</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>1.0</mn><mo> </mo><mi>M</mi></math> and <math alttext="the molar concentration of C o with a positive 2 charge, equals 0.20 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><msup><mi>Co</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>]</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace></mpadded><mo lspace="0.02em" rspace="0.02em">=</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>0.20</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></math>. How does the cell potential of this second galvanic cell compare to the cell potential of the first cell?

skill.text: 3.C: Represent visually the relationship between the structures and interactions across multiple levels or scales (e.g., particulate to macroscopic).
